A random sample of size \(n={@r1@}\) is taken from a large population with known standard deviation \(\sigma = {@r3@}\). If the sample mean is {@r2@}, calculate to 2 decimal places the following confidence intervals for the population mean \(\mu\):

The 90% confidence interval.    [3]

\(C.I._{90}\) = [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

[[feedback:Result1]]

The 95% confidence interval.    [3]

\(C.I._{95}\) = [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]

[[feedback:Result2]]

The 99% confidence interval.    [3]

\(C.I._{99}\) = [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]

[[feedback:Result3]]

If the sample of size \(n={@r1@}\) has a mean \(\bar x = {@r2@}\) and the population has a standard deviation \(\sigma={@r3@}\), then the sampling distribution of the mean follows a normal distribution:
\[
\bar X \sim N \left(\bar x,\frac{\sigma^2}{n}\right) = N \left({@r2@},\frac{{@r3@}^2}{{@r1@}}\right) = N \left({@r2@},{@decimalplaces(p1,2)@}\right)
\]

\[
P(-z < Z < z) = 0.9 \quad \iff \quad P(0 \le Z \le z) = 0.45
\]
Using the table of values, we find \(z = \pm 1.645\). Using the mean and standard deviation of the distribution of \(\bar X\), we can then recover 90% confidence interval.
\[
C.I._{90} = \bar x \pm 1.645 \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}} = {@r2@} \pm 1.645 \cdot {@decimalplaces(p2,2)@} = ({@decimalplaces(cl_1,2)@}, {@decimalplaces(cr_1,2)@})
\]
With 90% confidence, the population mean \(\mu\) is between {@decimalplaces(cl_1,2)@} and {@decimalplaces(cr_1,2)@}.

A random sample of size \(n={@p1@}\) is taken from a large population. The sample mean is \(\bar x = {@p2@}\), and the sample standard deviation is \(s = {@p3@}\).

Using this information, construct a 95% confidence interval for the population mean \(\mu\). Enter the interval using square brackets, separating the two values with commas \(\left[\dots ,\dots \right]\):    [2]

\(C.I._{95}\) = [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

[[feedback:Result1]]

questiontext.text:
A pair of dice is tossed {@r1@} times and the sum is seven {@r2@} times.

If the dice were fair, what would be the probability of the sum being seven? Round to 3 decimal places if required.    [3]

\(P\left(X = 7\right)\) = [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

[[feedback:Result1]]

We can reject the hypothesis that the dice are fair using a two tailed test at 5% significance. True or False?    [3]

= [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]]

[[feedback:Result2]]

We can reject the hypothesis that the dice are fair using a one tailed test at 5% significance. True or False? Explain which type of test you think is more appropriate in this case.    [3]

= [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]]

[[feedback:Result3]]

truefeedback.text:
With two dice, a throw will result in \(6^2=36\) possible pairs of faces. There are \(6\) possible ways that the sum of the two faces \(X\) can be \(7\):
\[
\begin{aligned}
1 + 6 \quad & \quad 2 + 5 \quad & \quad 3 + 4\\
4 + 3 \quad & \quad 5 + 2 \quad & \quad 6 + 1\\
\end{aligned}
\]
If the dice are fair, all 36 outcomes are equally probable and the probability is therefore:
\[P\left(X = 7 \right) = \frac{6}{36} = \frac{1}{6}\]

\]

The sample size is \(n={@r1@}\), therefore we can draw the critical values from the normal distribution.

The hypotheses we want to test are:
\[
\left\{\begin{aligned}
H_0: \, & p = \frac{1}{6} \\
H_1: \, & p \ne \frac{1}{6} \\
\end{aligned}\right.
\]

The test statistic is:
\[
t = \frac{\hat p - p}{\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}} = \frac{{@decimalplaces(p1,3)@}-\frac{1}{6}}{\sqrt{\frac{5}{36\times{@r1@}}}} = \frac{{@decimalplaces(p2,3)@}}{{@decimalplaces(p4,3)@}} = {@decimalplaces(p5,3)@}
\]

Given that we want 95% confidence on a two-tailed test with a sample size of \(n={@r1@}\), the critical value of the t-statistic is \(z_{0.05} = 1.96\). This tells us that \(t < z_{0.02}\), therefore there is {@txtB@}enough evidence to reject the null hypothesis that the dice are fair. The statement is {@solB@}.

\end{aligned}\right.

questiontext.text:
You are told that a random variable \(X\) has a population standard deviation of {@r3@}.

How large a sample \(n\) would you need in order to be able to estimate the population mean to within \(\pm\){@decimalplaces(r4,3)@} at the {@c3@}% confidence level? Round your answer up to an integer.    [2]

\(n\) = [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]]

[[feedback:Result1]]

truefeedback.text:
In order to determine how large a sample we need to achieve an error of \(\pm\){@decimalplaces(r4,3)@} at {@c3@}% confidence, we can invert the formula for the confidence interval, where \(z_{{@c3@}}\) is the critical value of the standard normal distribution. Suppose we pick the upper \(U_{{@c3@}}\) bound of the confidence interval:

\[
\begin{aligned}
U_{{@c3@}} & = \bar x + z_{{@c3@}} \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}\\
U_{{@c3@}} - \bar x & = z_{{@c3@}} \frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}\\
\sqrt{n} & =z_{{@c3@}} \frac{\sigma}{U_{{@c3@}} - \bar x} \\
n & = \left(z_{{@c3@}} \frac{\sigma}{U_{{@c3@}} - \bar x}\right)^2 \\
\end{aligned}
\]

The {@c3@}% critical value interval can be constructed using the standard normal distribution, but looking for the value of \(z_{{@c3@}}\) such that:
\[
P(-z_{{@c3@}} < Z < z_{{@c3@}}) = {@decimalplaces(p1_a,3)@} \quad \iff \quad P(0 \le Z \le z_{{@c3@}}) = {@decimalplaces(p1_b,3)@}
\]
Using the table of values, we find \(z_{{@c3@}} = {@decimalplaces(c4,3)@}\). Replacing this in the equation above, and including the information that the upper bound of the confidence interval should be {@decimalplaces(r4,3)@} above the mean, we can find the required sample size.

\[
n = \left({@decimalplaces(c4,3)@} \frac{{@r3@}}{{@decimalplaces(r4,3)@}}\right)^2 \approx \left({@decimalplaces(p3,3)@}\right)^2 \approx {@decimalplaces(p4,3)@}
\]
We need a sample of at least {@solA@} observations in order to generate a confidence interval of \(\pm\){@decimalplaces(r4,3)@} around the sample mean.
